Cummings analyzes campaigns
By JOE CANTOR
Dr. Milton Cummings,
Chairman of the Political Science
Department and election analyst
for NBC News, reviewed the
1972 Presidential campaign in a
post-mortem for the Wednesday
noon program.
Trying to account for what he
saw as the remarkable turn of
events this year, Cummings
discussed three developments and
three "non-events" which
contributed to the results last
week.
"Just consider where we stood
in January, 1972," said
Cummings. "Muskie was clearly
the front-runner for the
Democratic nomination,
McGovern was supported by only
three to five percent of the
people, Wallace was foreseen as a
third-party candidate in the fall,
Humphrey was expected to make
a weak showing, and everyone

thought Nixon was vulnerable."
Three central developments
were named by Cummings as
factors in reversing the situation:
Nixon's belated ability to
capitalize on the incumbency
(with the trips to China and
Russia, etc.), Wallace's removal
from the race as a potential
third-party candidate, and the
Democrats' nomination of
McGovern.
"There were also three
non-events which affected the
outcome," Cummings continued.
"the North Vietnamese troops
did not march into the streets of
Saigon this fall, the U.S.
economy did not go to hell in a
hearse, and the youth vote did
not jell in the way McGovern had
counted on."
"Because of the nature of his
primary campaign," Cummings
observed,"McGovern entered the
fall campaign with several bags of
•

concrete tied to him." Although
McGovern tried to move toward
the center, with good reason
according to Cummings, he was
not able to attract the massive
number of Democrats back into
the fold as Hubert Humphrey
had done in 1968.
"For all the campaigning
McGovern did," noted
Cummings, "there was not much
net movement during the fall —
as seen by comparing the 64-30
spread following Labor Day With
the final tally of 61-38."

election as a personal triumph for
Nixon, he noted that the
Democrats had managed to do
well on other levels. Although
the youth vote did not go
strongly for' McGovern,

showing that the ,under-30 year

A sickness in men that is somehow vital to their souls

By MARK CRISPIN MILLER
John Boorman's movie of James
Dicke y's gripping, stupid best-seller
Deliverance is playing at the Cinema
($2.50) in Washington, and is well worth
the price and drive. Although Dickey
wrote the screenplay, the movie and the
novel stand opposed, and it is the movie
that will survive (to put it in Dickey's
terms). Director Boorman brings to poet
Dickey's loud and hollow celebration of
self-discovery a blend of humaneness and
common sense that would have
benefitted the book, and that makes the
film a masterpiece.
Dickey's fierce wilderness and the
terrible things that happen there give the
narrator, Ed Gentry, a new awareness:
they "deliver" him. Boorman contradicts
everything Dickey says. His four
protagonists should never have gone on
their trip down the river. The film's title
is a complete irony. The film's wilderness
is not splendid or exotic, but a hazy,
dusty, monochromatic green-brown, full

of menacing shapes and unsettling,
overloud birdcalls. It contains within
itself no necessary secrets Its river may
be harsh, its sun merciless, but it's really
nothing more than a place where men can
come and prey on each other.
The real terror is not in the woods or
water, but in men; and the real secret is
that something evil lives in men. bobby, a
roly-poly gladhand fool- who can't say
anything that isn't bawdy, is buggered by
a mountain man in the film's central
scene. I say "central" because everything
the protagonists do somehow refers to
this harrowing sequence. The wilderness
is an unsupervised playground where
vicious little boys can play out their
phallic malice. Bobby's buggering is the
film's most blatant expression of the
same senseless machismo that dominates
this world of males. Ed's and Lewis'
arrows, the mountain man's shotguns,
Bobby's mindless attempt on his
attacker's arrow-skewered corpse: these
all signify a sickness in men that Dickey

sees as somehow vital to the soul. We put
down the novel and remember the river.
We think back on the movie, and those
corpses hidden in the river dominate our
remembrance as they will dominate Ed's
for all time, even as he lies in the arms of
his wife.
Here is the only decency in this
movie's grotesque world, among the
various women at the end. One of the
women at the boarding-house table
describes an enormous cucumber, reciting
its measurements with a slow twang. Is
she dull? Of course. But in her mild
surprise at the cucumber's size there is
refreshing mockery of that meaningless
obsession with male genitals that seems
to have driven all menfolk completely
crazy.
Boorman's outdoorsy Lewis (Burt
Reynolds) is somewhat like Dickey's glib
and shallow character. "The machines are
gonna fail," he says matter-of=factly,
stringing an elaborate, gadget-studded
bow and wearing a huge and intricate

sportsman's wristwatch. But there's also a
twisted aspect to Lewis' character that
we never find in the novel: he looks
longingly at Ed (Jon Voigt)in the light of
the campfire, and whimpers in his sleep.
Jon Voigt's Ed is a terrified, unwilling
fighter. He never revels in mere sensation
or examines the act of murder like a
curious aesthete. While the novel's Ed
suggests that he is a more complete
person for having the river within him,
the movie's Ed is only scared and guilty
for having become another killer in the
ragged wilderness.
Only a single disappointment
The movie is shot with exquisite
subtlety and unobtrusive imagination,
especially in light ot the obvious
difficulties entailed in shooting lucid
sequences on a raging river. One of the
best sequences (among many fine ones)
involves Drew, the only completely
untarnished of the four protagonists,
exchaning country music licks with a
rural idiot-boy at a backwoods gas

station., he pacing and editing of this
sequence, with its several bits of
simultaneous activity all leading up to a
few joygful moments of explosive music,
are every bit as impressive technically as
any of the action footage. Only once is
the technique at all disappointing. Ed's
moonlit climb up the cliff was shot in
daylight with a lot of filters, giving the

course, every member of the film crew,
including Voigt, would have broken his
ass if the sequence had been shot at
.night.)
In its technique and major
performances Deliverance is
unforgettable. It implies something true:
no vague transcendent thing awaits us in
the woods, but futile death and endless
cruelty outside the world, that Lewis
scorns so easily. Ed's experience is not
liberating, but shattering. Boorman
subverts all Dickey's highfalutin pretense
by showing us a rural world that no
amount of Hemingway could.redeem.

John Boorman's movie of James
Dickey's gripping, stupid best-seller
Deliverance is playing at the Cinema
($2.50) in Washington, and is well worth
the price and drive. Although Dickey
wrote the screenplay, the movie and the
novel stand opposed, and it is the movie
that will survive (to put it in Dickey's
terms). Director Boorman brings to poet
Dickey's loud and hollow celebration of
self-discovery a blend of humaneness and
common sense that would have
benefitted the book, and that makes the
film a masterpiece.
Dickey's fierce wilderness and the
terrible things that happen there give the
narrator, Ed Gentry, a new awareness:
they "deliver" him. Boorman contradicts
everything Dickey says. His four
protagonists should never have gone on
their trip down the river. The film's title
is a complete irony. The film's wilderness
is not splendid or exotic, but a hazy,
dusty, monochromatic green-brown, full

of menacing shapes and unsettling,
overloud birdcalls. It contains within
itself no necessary secrets Its river may
be harsh, its sun merciless, but it's really
nothing more than a place where men can
come and prey on each other.
The real terror is not in the woods or
water, but in men; and the real secret is
that something evil lives in men: bobby, a
roly-poly gladhand fool who can't say
anything that isn't bawdy, is buggered by
a mountain man in the film's central
scene. I say "central" because everything
the protagonists do somehow refers to
this harrowing sequence. The wilderness
is an unsupervised playground where
vicious little boys can play out their
phallic malice. Bobby's buggering is the
film's most blatant expression of the
same senseless machismo that dominates
this world of males. Ed's and Lewis'
arrows, the mountain man's shotguns,
Bobby's mindless attempt on his
attacker's arrow-skewered corpse: these
all signify a sickness in men that Dickey

sees as somehow vital to the soul. We put
down the novel and remember the river.
We think back on the movie, and those
corpses hidden in the river dominate our
remembrance as they will dominate Ed's
for all time, even as he lies in the arms of
his wife.
Here is the only decency in this
movie's grotesque world, among the
various women at the end. One of the
women at the boarding-house table
describes an enormous cucumber, reciting
its measurements with a slow twang. Is
she dull? Of course. But in her mild
surprise at the cucumber's size there is
refreshing mockery of that meaningless
obsession with male genitals that seems
to have driven all menfolk completely
crazy.
Boorman's outdoorsy Lewis (Burt
Reynolds) is somewhat like Dickey's glib
and shallow character. "The machines are
gonna fail," he says matter-of=factly,
stringing an elaborate, gadget-studded
bow and wearing a huge and intricate

sportsman's wristwatch. But there's also a
twisted aspect to Lewis' character that
we never find in the novel: he looks
longingly at Ed (Jon Voigt)in the light of
the campfire, and whimpers in his sleep.
Jon Voigt's Ed is a terrified, unwilling
fighter. He never revels in mere sensation
or examines the act of murder like a
curious aesthete. While the novel's Ed
suggests that he is a more complete
person for having the river within him,
the movie's Ed is only scared and guilty
for having become another killer in the
ragged wilderness.

By MARK CRISPIN MILLER
John Boorman's movie of James
Dicke y's gripping, stupid best-seller
Deliverance is playing at the Cinema
($2.50) in Washington, and is well worth
the price and drive. Although Dickey
wrote the screenplay, the movie and the
novel stand opposed, and it is the movie
that will survive (to put it in Dickey's
terms). Director Boorman brings to poet
Dickey's loud and hollow celebration of
self-discovery a blend of humaneness and
common sense that would have
benefitted the book, and that makes the
film a masterpiece.
Dickey's fierce wilderness and the
terrible things that happen there give the
narrator, Ed Gentry, a new awareness:
they "deliver" him. Boorman contradicts
everything Dickey says. His four
protagonists should never have gone on
their trip down the river. The film's title
is a complete irony. The film's wilderness
is not splendid or exotic, but a hazy,
dusty, monochromatic green-brown, full

of menacing shapes and unsettling,
overloud birdcalls. It contains within
itself no necessary secrets Its river may
be harsh, its sun merciless, but it's really
nothing more than a place where men can
come and prey on each other.
The real terror is not in the woods or
water, but in men; and the real secret is
that something evil lives in men. bobby, a
roly-poly gladhand fool- who can't say
anything that isn't bawdy, is buggered by
a mountain man in the film's central
scene. I say "central" because everything
the protagonists do somehow refers to
this harrowing sequence. The wilderness
is an unsupervised playground where
vicious little boys can play out their
phallic malice. Bobby's buggering is the
film's most blatant expression of the
same senseless machismo that dominates
this world of males. Ed's and Lewis'
arrows, the mountain man's shotguns,
Bobby's mindless attempt on his
attacker's arrow-skewered corpse: these
all signify a sickness in men that Dickey

sees as somehow vital to the soul. We put
down the novel and remember the river.
We think back on the movie, and those
corpses hidden in the river dominate our
remembrance as they will dominate Ed's
for all time, even as he lies in the arms of
his wife.
Here is the only decency in this
movie's grotesque world, among the
various women at the end. One of the
women at the boarding-house table
describes an enormous cucumber, reciting
its measurements with a slow twang. Is
she dull? Of course. But in her mild
surprise at the cucumber's size there is
refreshing mockery of that meaningless
obsession with male genitals that seems
to have driven all menfolk completely
crazy.
Boorman's outdoorsy Lewis (Burt
Reynolds) is somewhat like Dickey's glib
and shallow character. "The machines are
gonna fail," he says matter-of=factly,
stringing an elaborate, gadget-studded
bow and wearing a huge and intricate

sportsman's wristwatch. But there's also a
twisted aspect to Lewis' character that
we never find in the novel: he looks
longingly at Ed (Jon Voigt)in the light of
the campfire, and whimpers in his sleep.
Jon Voigt's Ed is a terrified, unwilling

John Boorman's movie of James
Dickey's gripping, stupid best-seller
Deliverance is playing at the Cinema
($2.50) in Washington, and is well worth
the price and drive. Although Dickey
wrote the screenplay, the movie and the
novel stand opposed, and it is the movie
that will survive (to put it in Dickey's
terms). Director Boorman brings to poet
Dickey's loud and hollow celebration of
self-discovery a blend of humaneness and
common sense that would have
benefitted the book, and that makes the
film a masterpiece.
Dickey's fierce wilderness and the
terrible things that happen there give the
narrator, Ed Gentry, a new awareness:
they "deliver" him. Boorman contradicts
everything Dickey says. His four
protagonists should never have gone on
their trip down the river. The film's title
is a complete irony. The film's wilderness
is not splendid or exotic, but a hazy,
dusty, monochromatic green-brown, full

of menacing shapes and unsettling,
overloud birdcalls. It contains within
itself no necessary secrets Its river may
be harsh, its sun merciless, but it's really
nothing more than a place where men can
come and prey on each other.
The real terror is not in the woods or
water, but in men; and the real secret is
that something evil lives in men: bobby, a
roly-poly gladhand fool who can't say
anything that isn't bawdy, is buggered by
a mountain man in the film's central
scene. I say "central" because everything
the protagonists do somehow refers to
this harrowing sequence. The wilderness
is an unsupervised playground where
vicious little boys can play out their
phallic malice. Bobby's buggering is the
film's most blatant expression of the
same senseless machismo that dominates
this world of males. Ed's and Lewis'
arrows, the mountain man's shotguns,
Bobby's mindless attempt on his
attacker's arrow-skewered corpse: these
all signify a sickness in men that Dickey

We think back on the movie, and those
corpses hidden in the river dominate our
remembrance as they will dominate Ed's
for all time, even as he lies in the arms of
his wife.
